entry.title: Westland Explorers' Monument (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Westland Explorers' Monument (pictured), placed within an intersection, was seen as an obstruction and relocated, only to be replaced with an even larger monument?

entry.title: Cumulus Computer Corporation (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Cumulus Computer Corporation was sued over alleged unpaid T-shirts?

entry.title: A Man and His Dog (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the dog in A Man and His Dog was modelled after Thomas Mann's real-life dog Bauschan?

entry.title: Marmaduke Johnson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in 1674 Marmaduke Johnson was the first printer allowed in colonial America to operate his own printing press in Boston?

entry.title: HaSela haAdom (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Israeli song "HaSela haAdom", about illegal trips to Petra, was banned in Israel?

entry.title: Jemma Mitchell case (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the sentencing phase of the Jemma Mitchell case was the second to be filmed in England and Wales since a change in the law permitted television cameras into court?

entry.title: a California TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the opening day of a California TV station was affected by a strike when workers refused to cross a two-man picket line?

entry.title: Marrow of the Red Phoenix (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Marrow of the Red Phoenix was composed by the "Daoist Confounded by Plum Blossoms"?
